messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 23, 2016 - March 29, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-31T01:04:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160331-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The Kp reached values of Kp=4 during the synoptic periods of 20016-03-23T06:00Z-09:00Z, 2016-03-28T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2016-03-30T12:00Z-15:00Z.  The slight increase of geomagnetic activity at the end of the reporting period was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-03-27.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-03-23T05:00Z     ~503            C                10/23                20                          SOHO, STEREO A                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-04-05T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Some active regions present on the solar disk have low magnetic complexity.  However, an active region on the far side has been developing and producing coronal mass ejections.  The geomagnetic activity may become slightly enhanced due to a coronal hole high speed stream expected to arrive around 2016-04-01.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-23T22:52:59Z
## Message ID: 20160323-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-03-23T05:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~503 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 10/23 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-03-23T05:00:00-CME-001

 
Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-03-26T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-03-23T05:00:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160323_112600_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 16, 2016 - March 22, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-23T19:32:05Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160323-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest Kp=5 value occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-03-16T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2016-03-16T21:00Z-24:00Z, and 2016-03-17T00:00Z-06:00Z. This slight elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 starting around 2016-03-14.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was enhanced on 2016-03-16 due to the CME starting on 2016-03-16T07:00Z, but remained below the threshold of 10 pfu for the entire reporting period.   The 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-03-16T03:12Z     ~570            C               114/19                28                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-03-16T07:00Z     ~670            C                90/1                 44                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-03-29T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Overall, the active regions on the Earth-facing solar disk show low magnetic complexity.  However, active region 12524 has been producing some flare activity in the last couple of days. The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate due to an expected coronal hole high speed stream arrival.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 09, 2016 - March 15, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-16T20:15:52Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160316-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 5 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-03-11T12:00Z-15:00Z. This elevation in geomagnetic activity was possibly associated with an interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 at 2016-03-11T04:21Z from a coronal mass ejection associated with an eruption visible on the center solar disk starting on 2016-03-08T03:50Z, but that could not be detected by any of the coronagraph imagery.  Strong compression of the magnetosphere was also detected at this time. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-03-11T13:00Z (see notifications  20160311-AL-001 and 20160311-AL-002).  

Geomagnetic activity also reached levels of Kp=5 (minor) during the synoptic periods of 2016-03-14T21:00Z-24:00Z and 2016-03-15T18:00Z-21:00Z due to a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 starting on 2016-03-14T16:20Z. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period, although they were elevated on 2016-03-09 due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-03-06.   

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)                      
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-03-13T20:36Z     ~579            C               -68/-13               21                          SOHO         
2016-03-10T15:24Z     ~535            C              -107/-13               25                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2016-03-10T19:33Z     ~650            C                90/25                12                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-03-14T18:12Z     ~544            C               -90/-19               19                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-03-15T06:48Z     ~590            C                95/50                32                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-03-22T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Overall, the active regions on the solar disk show low magnetic complexity. The geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate as the we are still under the effects of the coronal hole high speed stream described above detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-03-14.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-11T15:43:10Z
## Message ID: 20160311-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-03-11T12:00Z to 2016-03-11T15:00Z. 

The storm is resulted from the solar wind transient starting around 2016-03-11T04:21Z (2016-03-11T04:21:00-IPS-001), likely due to the CME on 2016-03-08 that didn't get detected by the coronagraph images. 

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-03-11T12:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 




NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-11T13:55:08Z
## Message ID: 20160311-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-03-11T13:00Z.

The activity is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2016-03-11T04:21:00-IPS-001.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2016-03-11T13:00:00-MPC-001.

## Notes

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 02, 2016 - March 08, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-09T20:49:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160309-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=7 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-03-06T21:00Z to 2016-03-07T00:00Z.  This strong increase in geomagnetic activity was possibly associated due to the combined effects on 2016-03-06 of the arrival detected by ACE at L1 of a coronal mass ejection associated with a filament eruption near center disk that occurred on 2016-03-03 and a coronal hole high speed stream (see notifications 20160306-AL-002 and 20160307-AL-001).  The solar wind speed reached values of 632 km/s on 2016-03-07.  Also, the combined effects produced a strong compression of the magnetopause boundary.   Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma crossed geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-03-06T16:32Z (see notification 20160306-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period, although they were slightly elevated on 2016-03-08 due to the coronal hole high speed stream effects described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 
 
CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-03-15T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  Overall, the active regions on the solar disk show low magnetic complexity.  However, there is an active region just rotating into the Earth's facing solar disk that has been producing some flare activity and has shown some continual growth. The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low as the effects of the high speed stream described above continue to diminish.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Auto-generated Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-07T00:34:01Z
## Message ID: 20160307-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 7 (strong) during the synoptic period 2016-03-06T21:00Z to 2016-03-07T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-03-06T09:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-03-06T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2016-03-06T04:30:00-IPS-001 and Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2016-03-06T16:32:00-MPC-001 (see notification(s) 20160306-AL-001).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-06T21:48:55Z
## Message ID: 20160306-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-03-06T18:00Z to 2016-03-06T21:00Z. 

The storm is possibly caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-03-06T09:00Z, and the arrival of a CME from a filament eruption on 2016-03-03.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-03-06T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 

This event is associated with Interplanetary Shock with ID 2016-03-06T04:30:00-IPS-001 and Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2016-03-06T16:32:00-MPC-001 (see notification(s) 20160306-AL-001).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-06T16:59:45Z
## Message ID: 20160306-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-03-06T16:32Z.

The activity is possibly associated with a high speed stream starting at 2016-03-06 and the arrival of a CME from a filament eruption on 2016-03-03.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2016-03-06T16:32:00-MPC-001.

## Notes

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 24, 2016 - March 01, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-02T21:43:46Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-03-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160302-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 4 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CMEs starting on 2016-02-27T04:39Z and 2016-03-01T08:48Z may impact Spitzer (glancing blow) around 2016-03-01T00:00Z and 2016-03-04T18:37Z, respectively (plus or minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20160227-AL-001 and 20160301-AL-001).   

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-02-24T14:12Z     ~530            C              -112/-26               25                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-02-27T04:39Z     ~597            C               -76/-20               23                          STEREO A                          
2016-02-27T05:48Z     ~553            C              -131/12                21                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-03-01T08:48Z     ~575            C               -75/5                 30                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-03-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-03-08T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There could be some minor activity originating from the several active regions present on the solar disk. Moderate enhancement of geomagnetic activity is possible around 2016-03-05 due to the onset of a coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes:

S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-03-01T15:05:50Z
## Message ID: 20160301-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-03-01T08:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~575 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 30 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -75/5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-03-01T08:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-03-04T18:37Z (plus/minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-03-01T08:48:00-CME-001):
